metadata.description: Conversational lesson content for practical Shona dialogue

lessons.title: Kuzvikwazisa - Introducing Yourself
lessons.description: Learn to introduce yourself and have basic conversations in Shona
culturalNotes: Introductions often include your family background
Asking about someone's totem (mutupo) is culturally significant

dialogues.title: Meeting Someone New
dialogues.scenario: Two people meeting for the first time

conversation.speaker: Person A
conversation.shona: Mhoroi, ini ndinonzi John. Munonzi ani?
conversation.english: Hello, I am called John. What are you called?
conversation.pronunciation: mm-HO-roi, i-ni ndi-no-nzi John. mu-no-nzi a-ni?

conversation.speaker: Person B
conversation.shona: Mhoroi John, ini ndinonzi Mary. Makadii?
conversation.english: Hello John, I am called Mary. How are you?
conversation.pronunciation: mm-HO-roi John, i-ni ndi-no-nzi Mary. ma-ka-di?

conversation.speaker: Person A
conversation.english: I am fine, how are you too?

conversation.speaker: Person B
conversation.english: I am fine. Where do you come from?

exercises.question: Complete the conversation: 'Mhoroi, ini ndinonzi Sarah. Munonzi ___?'
exercises.explanation: Use 'ani' to ask 'what' when asking for someone's name

exercises.scenario: Introduce yourself to a new colleague

lessons.title: Kubvunza Migwagwa - Asking for Directions
lessons.description: Learn to ask for and give directions in Shona

dialogues.title: Finding the Market
dialogues.scenario: Tourist asking for directions to the market

conversation.speaker: Tourist
conversation.english: Excuse me, where is the market?

conversation.speaker: Local
conversation.shona: Musika uri pedyo nezvikoro. Enda mberi, wobva wasvika.
conversation.english: The market is near the schools. Go forward, then you will arrive.
conversation.pronunciation: mu-si-ka u-ri pe-dyo ne-zvi-ko-ro. e-nda mbe-ri, wo-bva wa-svi-ka.

conversation.speaker: Tourist
conversation.english: Thank you. How long should I walk?

exercises.question: How do you say 'Where is the hospital?' in Shona?
exercises.explanation: Use 'chiripi' for 'where is' when referring to buildings/places

lessons.title: Mumusika - At the Market
lessons.description: Learn to bargain and shop at a traditional Shona market
culturalNotes: Bargaining is expected and shows engagement
Ask about the family - it's culturally important

conversation.speaker: Customer
conversation.english: Good morning mother. How much do the tomatoes cost?

conversation.speaker: Seller
conversation.shona: Mangwanani mwana. Tomato dziri madhora maviri pakg.
conversation.english: Good morning child. The tomatoes are two dollars per kg.
conversation.pronunciation: ma-ngwa-na-ni mwa-na. to-ma-to dzi-ri ma-dho-ra ma-vi-ri pa-kg.

conversation.speaker: Customer
conversation.shona: Aiwa, zvakanyanyisa. Mungatengesa madhora rimwe nehafu here?
conversation.english: No, that's too much. Can you sell for one dollar fifty?
conversation.pronunciation: ai-wa, zva-ka-nya-nyi-sa. mu-nga-te-nge-sa ma-dho-ra ri-mwe ne-ha-fu he-re?

exercises.question: Why is it important to greet the seller before asking about prices?
exercises.correctAnswer: It shows respect and cultural awareness
exercises.explanation: Greetings establish relationship and respect before business

lessons.title: Pamhuri - Family Conversations
lessons.description: Learn to talk about family and relationships in Shona

conversation.speaker: Friend B
conversation.shona: Mhuri yangu iriright. Baba vangu varipabasa, amai vangu varikumaruwa.
conversation.english: My family is fine. My father is at work, my mother is in the fields.
conversation.pronunciation: mhu-ri ya-ngu i-ri-right. ba-ba va-ngu va-ri-pa-ba-sa, a-mai va-ngu va-ri-ku-ma-ru-wa.

conversation.speaker: Friend A
conversation.english: Do you have an older brother or sister?

conversation.speaker: Friend B
conversation.shona: Ndine mukoma mumwe nehanzvadzi vaviri. Iwe?
conversation.english: I have one older brother and two sisters. And you?
conversation.pronunciation: ndi-ne mu-ko-ma mu-mwe ne-ha-nzva-dzi va-vi-ri. i-we?

exercises.question: Complete: 'Ndine _____ vaviri' (I have two sisters)
exercises.explanation: Use 'hanzvadzi' for sister in family context

lessons.title: Kubvunza Nguva - Asking About Time
lessons.description: Learn to ask about time and discuss schedules in Shona

conversation.speaker: Person B
conversation.english: It's twelve o'clock in the afternoon.

conversation.speaker: Person A
conversation.english: Thank you. What time do you finish work?

conversation.speaker: Person B
conversation.english: I finish work at five in the evening.

exercises.question: How do you ask 'What time is it?' in Shona?
exercises.explanation: Use 'Inguva ipi?' or 'Inguva ipi zvino?' to ask about time
